ygData.subject: Re: Genome compatibility and Euclidean distance
ygData.msgSnippet: Colin, thanks for the interesting point that we could alternatively compute a Euclidean distance in compatibility calculations.  I have to admit that I did not

Colin, thanks for the interesting point that we could alternatively
compute=
 a Euclidean distance in compatibility calculations.  I have to
admit that =
I did not reason through this issue to the extent people
have in this threa=
d when I first created NEAT.  For what it's worth,
because my original moti=
vation was the problem of topologies that are
not the same, my thinking was=
 most focused on identifying and counting
the excess/disjoint genes.  There=
fore, I think I agree with the view
that we should not assume dimensions to=
 exist that do not really exist
in a certain lineage (a view that you and P=
eter seem to be leaning
towards).  So that suggests keeping the current dis=
tance metric.

Yet what if we only computed Euclidean distance on the match=
ing genes?
 The disjoint/excess genes could still be counted separately.  S=
o the
measure would be kind of hybridized between two different kinds of
di=
stance.  But I'm not sure of the implication- what are the
advantages of th=
e Euclidean view of matching genes?  It would be
interesting to see experim=
ental results.

On the other hand, like many issues in NEAT, I am guessing =
the effect
would not be dramatic.  But it is still a good question.

ken 

=
--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_chervenski" <petar_chervenski@...>
wrot=
e:
>
> Hey I am thinking about this stuff a bit and.. I wonder if this is 
=
> similar to Novelty Search, where you can choose to have L1 or L2 or 
> wh=
atever distance between phenotype behavior data. 
> 
> But in NS usually th=
e behavior data is a fixed space. At the genetic 
> level, the genotype spa=
ce is unconstrained. Calculating distance 
> between points that lie in dif=
ferent spaces is a challenge. I even 
> wonder if this is possible at all..=
 
> 
> Take 2 random individuals from the first generation of a typical NEA=
T 
> evolution and they are all in the same space. Easy to compare. But 
> =
take 2 from the same population 1000 generations later and you will 
> find=
 out they are in completely different spaces. They may all branch 
> from t=
he initial minimal space, but the virtual coordinate frame that 
> should b=
e able to describe all possible individuals does not really 
> exist. Or do=
es it? 
> 
> In fact I guess it does. I can have a 100000+ neurons fully 
>=
 interconnected network and pretend it is the one ultimate space that 
> NE=
AT can search. Then I can assign coordinates to genomes based on 
> that sp=
ace. But this is misleading because NEAT effectively discovers 
> new space=
s during evolution.
> 
> So it is a process guided by discovery. Then I gue=
ss that genotypic 
> distance cannot be calculated more effectively than co=
mparing the 
> counts of excess/disjoint genes with respect of genomes. Ass=
igning 
> zeroes to missing links (assuming they exist with 0 weight) means=
 that 
> these individuals also share genetic history, but they don't. 
> 
=
> Peter 
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Colin Green" <colin.green1@> wr=
ote:
> >
> > I didn't address this point:
> > 
> > 2008/12/22 petar_cherven=
ski <petar_chervenski@>:
> > > Suppose that 2 genomes have many disjoint ge=
nes with respect
> > > to each other, if they are both represented as zeroe=
s, this would 
> mean
> > > they are closer in space?
> > 
> > Yes that's r=
ight. And this is effectively why I backtracked and
> > hypothesised that t=
he L1/manhattan distance (which is what we are
> > effectively using curren=
tly) is better than the L2/Euclidean 
> distance.
> > I think it would be a=
n interesting experiment to try out thse
> > different distance metrics and=
 see some experimental data to back up
> > the hypothesis.
> > 
> > Cheers,=

> > 
> > Colin.
> >
>
